This article is hogwash.  There is no such thing as "rogue" waves.  An ocean full of waves, a wavetrain, has waves of varying sizes.  If I remember correctly one wave in 300 will be twice the average wave height while one in 300,000 will be three times the average height.  These waves do not roam around the planet wreaking destruction, but exist for only moments as two or more waves combine and then just as quickly disperse.  A large wave in itself is not destructive; it is a breaking waves or waves that are dangerous.  A wave breaks as it gets higher (and often, shorter) until it becomes unstable, bends over, and then hundreds, thousands of tons of water cascade down its face.  Breaking waves are very destructive and dangerous to shipping, sometimes damaging or destroying even large, heavily-built steel ships.  Breaking waves are also caused by a current flowing against the wind (a Gulf Stream norther) or by the waves feeling the bottom as they pass over a shoal such as the Outer Banks, also known as the Graveyard of the Sea.

These waves occur when 2 or more wave patterns in the same area come together. When a wave crest from one meets a wave crest from another and they meet "in phase" they combine their heights at that point. It is called "constructive interference" in science and is not rare at all. Such extreme examples are not observed often but do exist often. I have seen large freighters disappear from view momentarily when such waves have formed between my vessel and theirs many times.

The extra height of a doubling is the result of two waves crossing, or of a bigger, faster wave overrunning a slightly smaller, slower wave. It happens often. When you see a sea speckled with white caps, each white cap is a double wave. When surfers wait for the sixth wave, they are waiting for the waves to double up. A tripling is just a double wave overrunning the next wave in front while still combined. Surfers wait for the 6th, 6th wave - the tripple. Happens often with small waves, so probably also happens often with large waves. Every sailor in a storm reports that there are big waves, then, after several waves, there is a bigger wave. Then, very occasionally, there is a really big wave. Just, usually not recorded.

Rogue waves can happen any time.  I was boating on Lake Mojave on the Colorado River, bow raised moderately, going against 3' - 4' waves out of the north.  Suddenly we got hit by a huge cross flow wave that went completely over the bimini top, swamped the deck, and washed out coolers out of the boat.  We were all stunned and then had to rush to retrieve our coolers from the drink in the rough waters.  We lost some food, but fortunately we saved the beer!  In 30+ years boating on the lakes of the Colorado, that was the only time I encountered something like that.
